item.title: Pokemon Is Getting a New Card Game
item.description:
Pokemon is introducing a new card game called Pokemon Taruka . The title is a play on a classic Japanese card game, and fans of the Pokemon franchise can get a look at what the card game consists of and how it's played.

Pokemon card games are extraordinarily popular among the franchise's fanbase. The Pokemon Trading Card Game has been wildly successful since its introduction in the 1990s, and it's since spawned mobile takes, like Pokemon Trading Card Game Live and Pokemon Trading Card Game Pocket . This new card game, however, is strictly physical for now, and is quite unlike the standard Pokemon TCG .

Pokemon is introducing its new Pokemon Taruka game, which is a variant of a classic Japanese card game called Karuta . Pokemon Taruka is, in essence, a matching game that's played competitively. Three people are necessary for a match. One person has their own set of cards, referred to as a reading deck, while the standard cards are spread out on a table or floor in front of the two competitors. The dealer reads their own card, which the two players must then use to identify the card they need to grab from the collection in front of them. Whoever grabs the correct card first is the winner of that round.

Pokemon Taruka's Uniqueness and Release Date

Pokemon Taruka , as the name might imply, changes up the formula from the standard Karuta game. The title is spelled backwards in the Japanese writing system from the standard card game, going from Ka-ru-ta to Ta-ru-ka. It's not just a naming convention, as the reader of the cards needs to read the cards backward, making it more difficult for the players and the dealer. The cards even cutely show the illustrations of the associated Pokemon dropped on their heads, with some of them looking quite uncomfortable and grumpy at their orientation. The Pokemon Company has shared a video demonstrating how it's played, albeit in Japanese.

Pokemon Taruka will start appearing in Pokemon Center stores on July 19, 2025. As the cards are written entirely in Japanese, and the Pokemon names are also their Japanese versions, it's highly unlikely that these cards will be available in Pokemon Center stores outside of Japan. Those who aren't fluent in the language would need a translated version, and given Karuta isn't extremely popular or well-known outside of Japan, that seems unlikely. Players who want them to play or collect will likely either need to go to Japan or purchase them from a reseller.

item.title: Valve’s Gabe Newell Reveals His Daily Routine
item.description:
During a recent interview, Valve co-founder Gabe Newell shared details about his daily life, describing everything from pastime activities to current work projects. Newell is known for avoiding the media as much as possible, so comments like these sometimes pop up out of nowhere, although the circumstances surrounding this interview are quite interesting. Despite staying out of the limelight, Newell continues working on projects at Valve and other companies, making his insight valuable to a wide audience.

Interviews with the industry titan are rare enough that even unconfirmed reports of Gabe Newell's addiction to Stalker 2 managed to garner some attention from fans in March 2025. The man behind the Steam platform is well known and respected within the gaming industry, and some fans will always be excited to learn more details about the outspoken tech executive's life and experiences.

In this most recent interview, Gabe Newell describes some of his daily activities, which include scuba diving, working out, and more. The creative mind behind Half-Life also commented on his daily work regimen. Newell chose Zalkar Saliev, a YouTuber with 19 subscribers, to do the interview, which has since been confirmed as legitimate by PC Gamer. Given Newell's history of interaction with fans, this decision oddly makes a lot of sense.

Gabe Newell Comments on Work Ethic and Daily Life

The Valve co-founder also noted that he works seven days a week from his bedroom, stating that "to me, it doesn't feel like work." Newell clarified his statement by explaining that "the kinds of things that I get to do every day are super awesome," which is undoubtedly very true. Afterward, the industry icon went on to say that "when you retire, you want to...stop doing your horrible job and then go do sort of what is most fun and entertaining, and so...in that sense, I've been retired a long time."

While even Newell admits there's nothing new about this sentiment, it seems his lived experience is proving that philosophy to be true. In that sense, it could be argued that the gaming mogul had some valuable words of wisdom for his fans in this interview. In addition to these comments, Newell admitted to working on several projects, including some work on "AI stuff" and "Steam stuff." While the PC gaming pioneer did not go into detail about these projects, it's worth noting that this comment comes shortly after the revelation that almost 8,000 Steam titles use Generative AI.

Of course, Steam isn't the only way to gauge the industry's stance on AI, as even the new Co-CEO of Ubisoft's latest subsidiary suggests that this technology will play a role in the publisher's future. It seems that no matter how gamers feel about the use of Generative AI, some developers and publishers are still hoping to take advantage of artificial intelligence when creating new titles. That said, it's important to keep in mind that Newell's comments here were offhanded, so there's no way of knowing exactly what kind of AI technology the developer could be working on at the moment.

item.title: Destiny 2 Making Big Change to Bright Dust and Removing Pathfinder System
item.description:
Following the controversy surrounding the recent changes to many of Destiny 2 's core mechanics, Bungie has announced plans to make Bright Dust a resource that players can farm for infinitely in an update set to arrive later this year. While Bright Dust and the pace of earning cosmetics aren't quite at the top of the game's problem list right now, this change should help players feel more rewarded for their time investment in the long run. It will be bolstered by another change coming later in 2025 that plans to replace Destiny 2 's Pathfinder function with a new, even easier daily objective system.

Destiny 2 's currency ecosystem has been in pretty constant flux over the past several years, and many players have hoped for a method that allows them to earn Bright Dust more consistently. This particular resource is essentially the game's freely earned parallel to its premium currency, Silver, and can be used to purchase a range of cosmetic items such as legendary armor ornaments, emotes, sparrows, weapon skins, and more. The selection of items that can be bought with Bright Dust rotates each week, though some things in Destiny 2 's in-game store, such as certain armor ornament sets, typically can't be unlocked with Bright Dust.

With players currently only able to earn a limited amount of Bright Dust in Destiny 2 from various challenges each week, Bungie has announced plans to add a new source of the currency that players will be able to farm limitlessly. This change is planned to arrive later in the year with the Renegades expansion, and will help Guardians chase the cosmetics they're after without having to spend real money. More importantly, though, this change should help players feel more adequately rewarded for the time they put into the game and its various activities, assuming Bungie implements the planned feature in a way that works comfortably for players.

This Change Is One Small Step Toward Solving One of Destiny 2's Biggest Issues

Further, Bungie plans to replace the Pathfinder system - a feature that was only introduced last year with The Final Shape expansion - with an easier and less complex daily challenge system. This change is set to come later in 2025 with Destiny 2 's Renegades expansion and will provide an unlimited number of simple challenges for players to chip away at to ensure that gameplay feels more rewarding, regardless of the activity playlist they choose. It seems like the Pathfinder exclusive to the Pale Heart destination will remain unaffected by these future changes.

The launch of Destiny 2 's new Edge of Fate expansion has brought big changes to plenty of existing systems, from armor stats to UI, although many of the latest tweaks to the game have been met with harsh criticism from players. A declining number of total players and monumentally low player count on the launch day of Destiny 2 's latest expansion has left many concerned about the game's direction and its future as a whole as it enters a completely new saga.

item.title: Why The Latest Marvel's Blade Leak Provides More Questions Than Answers
item.description:
It's going to cost a pretty penny to get Marvel's Blade out the door, according to recent reports. According to French government documents shared by Twitter user bogorad22, Marvel's Blade has a budget of around $109 million, raising questions about its scale and ambition, especially as audiences grapple with the disappointing news of its late development start.

For context, 2018's Marvel's Spider-Man cost about $100 to produce, while Marvel's Spider-Man 2 's budget infamously ballooned to over $300 million.

As many clued into the games industry are already aware, AAA titles are far from cheap. It's gotten to the point where many have questioned the sustainability of the AAA model, as companies are taking greater financial risks in the hopes of earth-shattering returns. Perhaps this is a response to the game industry's rampant growth during the COVID pandemic, which some publishers and developers may have assumed to be the new status quo for the industry year-over-year. That's obviously not been the case, but if games like Marvel's Blade continue to boast nine-figure budgets, it's only natural to wonder where exactly that money is going.

Marvel's Blade Has a High Price Tag, but What Will the Money Be Spent On?

Marvel's Blade Could Be More Ambitious Than First Assumed

Blade has always been an interesting part of Marvel's mainstream entertainment tapestry: he is seemingly beloved by many, with the Wesley Snipes films of the 90s and 2000s holding a special place in fans' hearts, but he's also a bit hard done by. The Blade film is reportedly stuck in development hell, for instance, and he's been virtually absent from the MCU altogether thus far.

So, while it may make sense to spend hundreds of millions on a game based on a character like Spider-Man, the decidedly less-popular Blade would be a tougher sell, one would imagine.

Unless the Blade game is destined for greater things, that is. Perhaps Arkane Lyon is planning to set Marvel's Blade in a huge, open-world Paris—something that wouldn't come cheap, that's for sure. Or perhaps Arkane is securing premium voice talent for some of its characters, scooping up big-name actors with big-name price tags.

It's hard to say, but it's safe to assume that Arkane Lyon and its parent company, ZeniMax Media, wouldn't feel comfortable shelling out so much cash on a B-list Marvel character unless there was a significant reason for doing so. Whatever the specifics, players will have to hope that Marvel's Blade makes the most of its alleged $109-million budget, lest it become another financial disaster for Arkane.

Hopefully, Blade Will Use Its Considerable Budget Wisely

A hefty budget can be a boon for any developer, but it can also come with a cost of its own. Whoever foots the $100-million bill is going to want a sizable return on their investment, but not every game manages to generate that much revenue, let alone two or three times that amount. A game has to be something truly special to make that sort of return, so if Marvel's Blade is just another open-world superhero game, that probably won't cut it.

Of course, Arkane Lyon would probably claim that Marvel's Blade is worth every penny of that $100-million budget, but that's its job; only time and gaming audiences at large will determine if Marvel's Blade truly made good use of its considerable resources. It's also worth noting that the past few years have been unkind to Arkane Studios: Redfall flopped, and Microsoft shut down Arkane Austin just last year as a result.

item.title: All Rocket Sidearms In Destiny 2, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Rocket Sidearms like Indebted Kindness are great for clearing enemies and triggering effects; ideal for PvE.
  • Aberrant Action offers explosive chaining ability with Incandescent perk; better for PvE with a solid roll.
  • The Call is a top choice for add-clear in Strand builds, benefits from unique traits; ideal for PvE usage.

The Rocket Assisted Frame is one of the most popular weapon archetypes in Destiny 2 . Ever since the first of them popped out of the Warlords Ruin Dungeon during Season of The Wish, Guardians were eager to try one of these beauties for their builds. The combination of a light weapon and the properties of rocket launchers creates a great option to cause serious damage from a safe distance, and they are also really fun to play.

No other weapon is so consistent when it comes to clearing hordes of rank-and-file enemies, while also breaking apart challenging enemies and even bosses. These are all Rocket Sidearms, with important info on their specs, the best Perks for PvP and PvE, and a detailed summary of which builds are best to use them for.

Updated July 18, 2025, by Lucas Simons: With the release of The Edge of Fate, a new Rocket Sidearm has been added to the game: Returned Memory has kicked some of the most effective weapons of this Archetype Behind, with its great combination of perks and stability, making it even more reliable than Aberrant Action as a Scorch propagation weapon. Some of the guns have received slight modifications to their perk pools and stats, so Guardians should take a look at them in case they are fond of these Special Ammo Energy Sidearms. If players really want to prepare for this new Meta that has arrived, they should pick one of the Rocket-Assisted Frame Sidearms from the list, which includes a lot of details about their God Rolls, and how to use them effectively in both PvP and PvE activities.

8 Indebted Kindness

The First Of Many, And A Great Equalizer

  • Range: 25m
  • Velocity: 56
  • Blast Radius: 35
  • Stability: 48
  • Handling: 45
  • Reload Speed: 28
  • Aim Assistance: 80
  • Zoom: 18
  • Airborne Effectiveness: 11

When Season of The Wish arrived in Destiny 2 , Guardians were tremendously excited about a new weapon archetype that was going to make its debut in the game, and it was an absolute blast. The Rocket Assisted Frame Sidearms, also known as Rocket Sidearms, was first presented to the players with the Indebted Kindness Arc energy sidearm, which uses Special Ammo, like any other Sidearms of the same archetype. Indebted Kindness is a notoriously good weapon, great for clearing waves of enemies, and for triggering Arc-related effects such as Amplified, Blind, and Jolt.

Of all the currently available Rocket Sidearms, it boasts the lowest stats between blast radius and projectile velocity, which are the most important stats for these weapons. Damage fall-off begins at range 10.4m-(10.5m) which is considerably good for an energy weapon of this caliber. All things considered, it is a great option for Guardians looking for that extra damage in High Tier Difficulty Ops, like Dungeons and Grandmaster Nightfall.

In PvP, Indebted Kindness is not as good as other Special Ammo weapons, but if players insist on making it part of their build, then the ideal roll for it should have Quick Launch, High-Velocity Rounds , Impulse Amplifier, and Adagio, with Velocity Masterwork. For PvE it depends on what players need to build in a similar way: with Quick Launch , High-Velocity Rounds, Impulse Amplifier or Beacon Rounds, and Voltshot or Surrounded. The PvE God Roll should also have Velocity as its masterwork, but Reload Speed can be considered a good alternative.

7 Aberrant Action

The Best Way To Spread Scorch Among Enemies

  • Range: 35m
  • Velocity: 56
  • Blast Radius: 35
  • Stability: 48
  • Handling: 45
  • Reload Speed: 28
  • Aim Assistance: 80
  • Zoom: 18
  • Airborne Effectiveness: 11

Aberrant Action is the latest addition to the Rocket Sidearm family and a Solar Energy one at that. This gives it access to a particularly great perk most Destiny 2 players have learned to love: Incandescent. This perk causes kills from this gun to spread a scorching explosion every time an enemy dies, and when scorch stacks up it also triggers another explosion called Ignition. With its intrinsic trait Radiolaria Transistor, it creates ponds of damaging energy upon killing several enemies in a row. This means players can create a chain reaction of non-stop explosions wherever they aim, if they do it right, of course. Another of the strong points of this weapon is that it boasts an even higher range than other Rocket Sidearms and this makes its damage fall-off trigger later than the average Rocket Assisted Frame Sidearm, at an 11m-(13.2m) threshold.

The PvE God Roll consists of Quick Launch, Flared Magwell , Heal Clip, and Incandescent. For Masterwork, players should consider Velocity - it makes projectiles travel faster and thus, hit targets sooner. For PvP, the ideal Roll would be Countermass High-Velocity Rounds, Threat Detector, and Harmony. The weapon handling and ready speed of the Threat Detector perk combined with the Harmony perk is perfect for landing the last shot during heated fights, especially against more than one opponent. Nevertheless, Aberrant Action is definitely better suited for PvE, and since fans can basically scorch dozens of enemies and constantly heal, it has become one of the greatest options now that healing abilities have been greatly nerfed.

6 The Call

This Is What Cayde Meant By Golden Age Ray Gun

  • Range: 30m
  • Velocity: 60
  • Blast Radius: 31
  • Stability: 35
  • Handling: 40
  • Reload Speed: 35
  • Aim Assistance: 70
  • Zoom: 18
  • Airborne Effectiveness: 14

The Call was brought with The Final Shape update and it came with a new intrinsic trait named Dealer's Choice that grants Super energy the more enemies players kill with this beauty. And since it's a Strand Primary Rocket Sidearm, it has become a staple part of every strand-based build since its launch. The Call greatly benefits from Unraveling Rounds and Threadling synergies, and no other primary has such an effective add-clear kit. Arguably, the second best choice for a Rocket Sidearm, its God Roll for PvE consists of Linear Compensator , High Velocity Rounds, Subsistence, and One-for-All or Hatchling for more add-clear power.

Every time Hatchling activates in a mass of enemies, it will also trigger other effects of the Strand Subclass, meaning that players can consistently pair it with Unraveling Rounds and Sever and it can also synergize with Fragments that empower said effects and grant powerful buffs like Woven Mail, or boost the spawn of Tangles. In other words, this weapon is designed for PvE purposes, but if players are also looking for the PvP God Roll, they should pick the following: Quick Launch, High Velocity Rounds, Beacon Rounds, Vorpal Weapon, and of course, the Velocity Masterwork.

5 Returned Memory

Great Control, Add Clear And Stability

  • Range: 40m
  • Velocity: 54
  • Blast Radius: 35
  • Stability: 52
  • Handling: 44
  • Reload Speed: 32
  • Aim Assistance: 85
  • Zoom: 13
  • Airborne Effectiveness: 12

Returned Memory is one of the finest weapons introduced in The Edge of Fate, with great control, stability, and precision, this weapon doesn't feel like the average Rocket-Assisted Frame Sidearm. It's projectiles cause Solar damage on impact, it has a decent Blast Radius, and comes with a lot of powerful perks that are mainly useful for PvP. With Beacon Rounds and Burning Ambition, the Returned Memory becomes a true menace on the battlefield, marking enemy Guardians and scorching them for DoT damage in a 35-meter radius. This weapon is so effective that it can sweep an entire rival fire team if caught unprepared.

With a slight change to its perks, Blast Distributor (one of the newest perks that grants Grenade Stats whenever the player causes Splash damage with the weapon) and Incandescence, players can practically gain infinite Grenade Energy, for as long as they have Special Ammo, that is. But that's where the Special Ammo Energy generation mods come into play, and since the weapon can be Masterworked using Enhancement Cores, players can add the Abundant Ammo or Bandolier mods to make this weapon contribute to ammo generation even more. Complete with Volatile Launch (Barrel) and High-Explosive Ordnance (Magazine) for extra Blast Radius, and Guardians will obtain the best Special Ammo add clear they can get.

4 Lotus-Eater

A Void Rocket Sidearm With An Incredible Perk Combination

  • Range: 40m
  • Velocity: 34
  • Blast Radius: 36
  • Stability: 47
  • Handling: 47
  • Reload Speed: 55
  • Aim Assistance: 69
  • Zoom: 18
  • Airborne Effectiveness: 30

It was about time that a Legendary Void Rocket Sidearm made its debut in Destiny 2. Even though players are quire happy with Buried Bloodline, the Lotus-Eater comes to challenge its reign of terror, with a unique combination of perks primed for Void builds that rely on Volatile Rounds and Overshield. Its god-roll for PVE consists of Destabilizing Rounds and Repulsor Brace , a combo that generates incredible explosions and infinite Overshield for all Void Build Guardians.

For PvP, this weapon has a particularly useful perk that enhances its combat effectiveness and damage by the heaps: Adrenaline Junkie. Powerful and reliable, this perk increases damage by up to 33% (at 5 stacks) as players kill enemies. It is also useful in PvE, but that would take one of the slots for more useful perks that are great for crowd control. This weapon can be obtained from the Nightfall Psy-Ops Battlegrounds: Cosmodrome.

3 Lotus-Eater (Adept)

Even Better Than The Regular Version, Though Harder To Get

  • Range: 40m
  • Velocity: 34
  • Blast Radius: 38
  • Stability: 47
  • Handling: 47
  • Reload Speed: 57
  • Aim Assistance: 69
  • Zoom: 18
  • Airborne Effectiveness: 30

The Adept version of the Lotus-Eater comes with incredibly enhanced Mods (as with other Adept weapons) and in this particular case, a little bump on base Blast Radius and reload speed. As with the regular version, Repulsion Brace in the left perk column, and Destabilizing Rounds is the go-to combo. But, there are different combos that are also useful, for example: Reconstruction Rounds and the new Perk introduced in Heresy: Withering Gaze.

In PvP, players should take advantage of those extra stats that come with the Adept Mods and get that Adept Projectile Speed Mod to make enemy guardians suffer in all PvP modes. They'll never know what hit them. A great option for PvP is having a roll that combines Quick Launch, High Velocity Rounds, Beacon Rounds, and High Ground, for maximum accuracy and damage.

2 Buried Bloodline

Heals, Weakens, Has High Damage, What Else Do You Need?

  • Range: 35m
  • Velocity: 87
  • Blast Radius: -5
  • Stability: 57
  • Handling: 55
  • Reload Speed: 36
  • Aim Assistance: 89
  • Zoom: 18
  • Airborne Effectiveness: 22

The best Rocket Sidearm, or should we say Crossbow, and up to the most recent addition of Warlord's Ruin to the weekly dungeon rotation, an extremely hard one to get. Buried Bloodline is an exotic Void energy sidearm, and has the following properties: It has an extremely reduced Blast Radius, meaning that its rounds will implode instead of exploding in a wider area, but thanks to its Hungering Quarrel perk, it shoots dual bolts of void energy, which track down the targets and can cause precision damage, healing the user upon hitting enemies.

Its intrinsic perk grants Devour to the Guardian when killing multiple targets in quick succession. Pairing this with Volatile Rounds is extremely efficient. Finally, its catalyst grants the weapon its ultimate form with the additional perk: Splitvein Lineage, which causes targets hit when Devour is active to be Weakened as well. All these properties pair up nicely with any Void build, but they are absolutely broken with a Void Hunter equipped with Gyrfalcon's Hauberk , or a Prismatic Hunter with its Exotic Class Item that has Spirit Of The Gyrfalcon among its perks. When doing so, killing with Buried Bloodline will trigger Void Rounds, Devour, Weaken, Overshield, and Invisibility simultaneously, making it the perfect weapon for a Stealth Hunter play.

1 Tinasha's Mastery

The Best Way To Cool Off Enemies

  • Range: 28m
  • Velocity: 56
  • Blast Radius: 35
  • Stability: 54
  • Handling: 42
  • Reload Speed: 29
  • Aim Assistance: 78
  • Zoom: 18
  • Airborne Effectiveness: 10

Tinasha's Mastery is the newest addition to the Rocket Pistol family, boasting one of the best perk combinations for a God Roll in any of the weapons of its Archetype: Impulse Amplifier and Chill Clip. These two can be used for both PvP and PvE, and guarantee a swift Stasis Damage and slow debuff delivery upon your enemies (and associates). Since every Rocket Pistol does Area damage (except Buried Bloodline) expect some cool AoE synergies with several Artifact Perks and Class Traits.

Stasis has been quite OP ever since Eclipse and continues to dominate the top picks for competitive players. So, having a Rocket Assisted Frame Pistol with Stasis element gives us shivers, quite literally, more so if it is in the right hands. There are other possible combinations for worthwhile Perks (especially in PvE) Enlightened Action with Bait And Switch could have damage potential, and the combination of Air Trigger and Chill Clip is also good for PvP.
